references: Burbrink, F. T., R. Lawson, and J. B. Slowinski. 2000. Mitochondrial DNA phylogeography of the North American rat snake (Elaphe obsoleta): A critique of the subspecies concept. Evolution 54:2107-2114.
Conant, R. and J. T. Collins. 1991. A field guide to reptiles and amphibians:eastern and central North America. Third edition. Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, Massachusetts. 450 pp.
NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
Burbrink, F. T. 2001. Systematics of the eastern ratsnake complex (Elaphe obsoleta). Herpetological Monographs 15:1-53.
habitat_description:
The range of this species encompasses areas of southwestern Illinois, southern South Dakota, Missouri, southeastern Colorado, and Texas. Disjunct populations have been reported in eastern Utah and western Colorado. In Mexico, populations occur from south of the Texas border to San Luis Potosi south into Veracruz (Burbrink 2002; Conant and Collins 1991).

Preferred habitats include riparian zones to more terrestrial habitats such as: bare rock, talus, scree, cropland, hedgerow, forest edge, forest woodland, grassland, savanna, shrubland, suburban, orchard, and conifer woodland. This species is known to burrow in soil, fallen logs, leaf litter, standing snag, and hollow trees (Natureserve.org).

Particular features of its occupied habitats where individuals can be observed include rocky hillsides, stream courses and river bottoms, canyons and arroyos, meadows, abandoned houses and farm buildings, caves, wooded areas, and barnyards.

SW	-Shrubland, savanna, grassland, various woodlands, suburban areas.
GP	-Forest edge, forest woodland, cropland, hedgerow, and conifer woodland.
